title: Replication of Government Datasets and the Principles of Provenance
content: As part of our Public Data Project, LIL recently launched Data.gov Archive Search. In this post, we consider the importance of provenance for large, replicated government datasets. This post is the third in a three-part series; the first introduces Data.gov Archive Search and the second explores its architecture.

content: This past week members of the Library Innovation Lab team traveled to Portland, Oregon to receive the Public Access to Government Information Award from AALL for our data.gov archive.

title: IIPC Web Archiving Conference 2025 Recap
content: The Perma team has landed back in the US after our trip to the International Internet Preservation Consortium‚Äôs Web Archiving Conference. This year the IIPC met in Oslo at the National Library of Norway, and the conference‚Äôs theme was ‚ÄúTowards Best Practices.‚Äù

title: Open French Law RAG: Using AI for Cross-Language Legal Information Retrieval
content: Imagine that you are an English speaker visiting France, engaged in discussion with a French local about a legal issue, but you are a novice French speaker and not familiar with the French legal system. Fortunately, you have a laptop containing over 800,000 French law articles, where the answer to your question may be found. You also have access to open-source software and a multilingual large lan
creator: Kristi Mukk, Matteo Cargnelutti and Betty Queffelec

title: Library Innovation Lab Announces the Launch of Institutional Data Initiative to Expand Access to Knowledge
content:
Cambridge, MA ‚Äì Harvard Law School‚Äôs Library Innovation Lab (LIL) is proud to announce the official launch of the Institutional Data Initiative (IDI), a groundbreaking program helping libraries, government agencies, and other knowledge institutions share digital collections with their patrons while improving the accuracy and reliability of AI tools for all.
First developed by Greg Leppert at the L
creator: Library Innovation Lab Team

title: Adding Fresher Caselaw To Open Casebooks
content:
This post relates to H2O Open Casebook, our tool for law professors to make open, remixable casebooks, and the Caselaw Access Project, our project to digitize the law of the United States.
H2O Open Casebook makes the law fresher for students by letting professors teach from recent and relevant cases instead of cases involving steam engines and horses.
Today we‚Äôre making that even easier by adding
creator: Jack Cushman

title: WARC-GPT ‚Äúon tour‚Äù: Talk transcript and slide decks
content:
Over the past couple of months, my colleague Kristi Mukk and I had the opportunity to talk about WARC-GPT and the concept of Librarianship of AI to the greater GLAM community:
In March, at an event organized by Harvard Library about AI at Harvard Library.
In April, at the 2024 Web Archiving Conference of the International Internet Preservation Consortium (IIPC), which was held in Paris.
In May, at

title: Student Note: ChatGPT Ate My Homework. Can LLMs Generate Compelling Case Briefs?
content:
The Library Innovation Lab welcomes a range of research assistants and fellows to our team to conduct independently-driven research which intersects in some way to our core work.
The following is a reflection written by Chris Shen, a Research Assistant who collaborated with members of LIL in the spring semester of 2024. Chris is a sophomore at Harvard College studying Statistics and Government.

content: The Perma team has landed back in the US after our trip to the International Internet Preservation Consortium‚Äôs Web Archiving Conference. This year the IIPC met in Paris, at the Biblioth√®que Nationale de France.

content:
I just made a minor
change to
WARC-GPT, the tool Matteo
Cargnelutti wrote for querying web archives with
AI. I‚Äôll
explain a little bit of the background, and what the change is for.
What are we trying to do here
The basic idea is that we want to combine web archives with an
existing large language model, so that the model will answer questions
using the contents of the web archive as well as its i
creator: Ben Steinberg

title: New Endeavors at the Library Innovation Lab
content: This month, the Library Innovation Lab celebrated the full and unqualified release of the Caselaw Access Project data. We took the opportunity to gather and look to the future at Transform: Justice on March 8th. The event reminded us of what we already knew: the open legal data movement is alive and well.
creator: Clare Stanton

title: Transitions for the Caselaw Access Project
content:
The Library Innovation Lab is excited to announce that the original limitations on the data available for the Caselaw Access Project expired this month, and that data can now be fully released without restriction on access or use.
As part of our original collaboration agreement with Ravel Law, Inc. (now part of LexisNexis) for the Caselaw Access Project there had been access limitations on the ful
creator: The Library Innovation Lab Team

title: Cracking the justice barrier: announcing the Open Legal AI Workbench
content:
This post is part of the Library Innovation Lab‚Äôs announcements in the context of Transform: Justice, celebrating the full, unqualified release of the data from the Caselaw Access Project.
When the Lexis corporation first launched legal research terminals in the 1970s it hoped to ‚Äúcrack the librarian barrier,‚Äù allowing lawyers to do their own legal research from their desks instead of sending law

title: The Cloud
content: How do you make the invisible visible? This is the central premise of The Cloud, a project that I‚Äôve been working on as a technologist in residence at LIL. The idea originated as a visual joke about the cloud: the vaporous metaphor we use to describe the distributed servers that host remotely-run software and infrastructure.
creator: Rebecca Kilberg

title: WARC-GPT: An Open-Source Tool for Exploring Web Archives Using AI
content:
Today we‚Äôre releasing WARC-GPT: an open-source, highly-customizable Retrieval Augmented Generation tool the web archiving community can use to explore the intersection between web archiving and AI. WARC-GPT allows for creating custom chatbots that use a set of web archive files as their knowledge base, letting users explore collections through conversation.
Using WARC-GPT, you can ask specific que

title: The Cost of a Digital Archive
content: At LIL, we‚Äôve been providing users with the ability to preserve online sources via Perma.cc since 2013. Running a digital archive puts us in the ‚Äúforever business‚Äù‚Äìwhat‚Äôs online today may be gone tomorrow, but that Perma Link you saved should never expire. Promising to host something forever brings with it different challenges than hosting something for a month or a year. There are the technical b
creator: Rebecca Kilberg

title: Welcoming Fellow Katy Gero
content: The LIL team is excited to welcome Katy Gero, who joins us to investigate ethical language models for creative writing. Katy is a post-doc at the Variation Lab at Harvard SEAS, which is led by friend of LIL Elena Glassman.
creator: Clare Stanton

title: LLMs are universal translators: on building my own translation tools for a foreign language conference
content:
Here is a picture of the Statue of Liberty doing a TikTok dance, as painted by van Gogh, as interpreted by ChatGPT. This is very relevant to my point and we‚Äôll come back to it.

One of the best ways to think about large language models is as universal, personal translators. When I gave a talk at a Spanish-language library conference in Argentina recently, it was an excellent chance to test what LL
creator: Jack Cushman

title: Conference talk: disruptive innovation in libraries
content:
This piece is adapted from a keynote talk I gave at Innovaci√≥n y Experiencia del Usuario at Universidad Cat√≥lica de Argentina on November 1, 2023.
I was asked to give a talk on the subject of ‚Äúdisruptive innovation in libraries,‚Äù which isn‚Äôt necessarily the phrase I would choose to describe our work, but I enjoyed using that lens to explore the changes all libraries are going through.
If you want
creator: Jack Cushman

title: AI Book Bans: Testing LLMs Against the Freedom to Read
content: What happens when large language models are asked to provide justifications for book bans? Do the same built-in guardrails that prevent them from generating pipe-bomb recipes kick in, or do models do their best to comply with the user‚Äôs request? How do models go about providing such justifications while navigating their ‚Äúknowledge‚Äù of library principles? And what could this all mean for the future

title: Mysterious Search Algorithms
content: Lawyers use search algorithms on a daily or even hourly basis, but the way they work often remains mysterious. Users receive pages and pages of results from searches that ostensibly are based on some relevancy standard, seemingly guaranteeing that the most important results are all found. But that may not always be the case. This post explores the mystery of search algorithms from a legal research
creator: William Yao

title: "Did ChatGPT really say that?": Provenance in the age of Generative AI.
content:
Prompt:
‚ÄúWrite a single sentence summarizing why cryptographically-signed provenance information matters in the context of AI-generated content.‚Äù
ChatGPT:
‚ÄúCryptographically-signed provenance information matters in the context of AI-generated content to establish trust, transparency, and authenticity by providing a verifiable record of the content‚Äôs origin, authorship, and creation process.‚Äù
That‚Äô
creator: Matteo Cargnelutti

title: Witnessing the web is hard: Why and how we built the Scoop web archiving capture engine üç®
content: There is no one-size-fits-all when it comes to web archiving techniques, and the variety of tools and services available to capture web content illustrate the wide, ever-growing set of needs in the web archiving community. As these needs evolve, so do the web and the underlying challenges and opportunities that capturing it presents. Our decade of experience running Perma.cc has given our team a v
creator: Matteo Cargnelutti

title: Introducing Reading Mode for H2O
content:
We are excited to announce the release of our ‚Äúreading mode‚Äù - a new casebook view that offers students a cohesive digital format to facilitate deep reading.
We think better design of digital reading environments can capture the benefits of dynamic online books while orienting readers to an experience that encourages deeper analysis. Pairing that vision with our finding that more students are seek
creator: Catherine Brobston

title: IIPC Technical Speaker Series: Archiving Twitter
content:
I was invited by the International Internet Preservation Consortium (IIPC) 
to give a webinar on the topic of ‚ÄúArchiving Twitter‚Äù on January 12.
During this talk, I presented what we‚Äôve learned building thread-keeper, the experimental open-source software behind social.perma.cc which allows for making high-fidelity captures of twitter.com urls as ‚Äúsealed‚Äù PDFs.
creator: Matteo Cargnelutti

title: Towards "deep fake" web archives? Trying to forge WARC files using ChatGPT.
content:
Chatbots such as OpenAI‚Äôs ChatGPT are becoming impressively 
good at understanding complex requests in ‚Äúnatural‚Äù language and generating convincing blocks of 
text in response, using the vast quantity of information the models they run were trained on.
Gartner Hype Cycle, ChatGPT and its 
potential amazes and fascinates as much as it bewilders and worries. 
In particular, more and more people seem
creator: Matteo Cargnelutti

title: ChatGPT: Poems and Secrets
content:
I‚Äôve been asking
ChatGPT to write some
poems. I‚Äôm doing this because it‚Äôs a great way to ask ChatGPT how it
feels about stuff ‚Äî and doing that is a great way to understand
all the secret layers that go into a ChatGPT output. After looking 
at where ChatGPT‚Äôs opinions come from, I‚Äôll argue that
secrecy is a problem for this kind of model, because it overweighs the
risk that we‚Äôll misuse this tool o
creator: Jack Cushman

title: Ethical Collaborative Storytelling
content: I started with the idea of a computer-generated story in which audience participation creates copies of the narrative from each person‚Äôs point of view. The story would evolve in real time as new users joined and each person‚Äôs copy would update accordingly. I called the story Forks. After some initial trials, I decided not to launch it because I did not believe the project was securable against har
creator: Liza Daly

title: Welcome Molly White: Library Innovation Lab Fellow
content:
The Harvard Library Innovation Lab is delighted to welcome Molly White as an academic fellow.
Molly has become a leading critic on cryptocurrency and web3 issues through her blog Web3 is Going Just Great as well as her long-form research and essays, talks, guest lectures, social media, and interviews. Her rigorous, independent, and accessible work has had a substantial impact on legislators, media
creator: Jack Cushman

title: H2O usability study: do students want physical casebooks?
content: This summer, one of our research assistants, Seonghee Lee, ran a study among current law students that is helping us reconsider some longstanding assumptions about student reading preferences and informing future development of the H2O Open Casebook platform.
creator: Catherine Brobston

title: Web Archiving: Opportunities and Challenges of Client-Side Playback
content:
Historically, the complexities of the backend infrastructures needed to play back and embed rich web archives on a website have limited how we explore, showcase and tell stories with the archived web. Client-side playback is an exciting emerging technology that lifts a lot of those restraints.
The replayweb.page software suite developed by our long-time partner Webrecorder is, to date, the most ad
creator: Matteo Cargnelutti

title: What Legal Hackers Can Learn From Libraries
content: This is a lightly edited transcript of a talk I gave at the 2022 Legal Hackers International Summit on September 10, 2022.
creator: Jack Cushman

title: IIPC 2022 Recap
content: This past week was the annual gathering of the International Internet Preservation Consortium. This year, the event was hosted online by the Library of Congress, and we were excited to be able to attend sessions from folks all over the globe.
creator: Clare Stanton

title: 2021 Research Associates
content: Like most things at LIL, our visiting researcher program has taken many forms over the years. This year, despite our team being spread across the East and Midwest Coasts (shout out to Lake Michigan) we were thrilled to welcome five research associates to the virtual LILsphere, to explore their interests through the lens of our projects and mission.
creator: Clare Stanton

title: Interface Upgrade | Integrating Queries into Search and Case View
content: With expanded feature capabilities, users may find writing these queries to be more difficult, especially as researchers increase the complexity of their investigations. To make usage easier, we have integrated the Trends query language into the Search and Case View features. From a search query, users can click the Trends button, upon which our servers will automatically convert an existing query
creator: Andy Gu

title: New Feature | Flexible Citation Queries
content: Expand your ability to visualize citation practices with the latest support added to our Trends tool. Trends now supports flexible queries of how cases cite other cases in addition to the other ways in which cases can be filtered. By appending the name of any acceptable filter parameter to cites_to__{parameter name here}, users can retrieve all cases citing to cases matching said filter. The param
creator: Andy Gu

title: Feature Update | Extension of Trend Search Capability
content: Today, we are announcing an update to the Caselaw Access Project (CAP) API and Trends tool to help users better investigate changes in the law over time. These new features enable users to easily generate timelines of cases and explore patterns in case citations. We hope that they can help researchers uncover new insights about American caselaw.
creator: Andy Gu

title: Download PDFs of Cases by Citation with CAP
content: Today we‚Äôre announcing Fetch PDFs, a simple tool to find case citations in text and give you links to scanned PDFs of those cases from CAP.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Updates to Case Display - Headmatter
content: The Caselaw Access Project offers free, public access to over 6.5 million decisions published by state and federal courts throughout American history. Because our mission is providing access to legal information, we make these decisions available in a variety of formats through a variety of different access methods.

title: Search Update: Download Search Results as Dataset
content: The Caselaw Access Project offers free, public access to over 6.5 million decisions published by state and federal courts throughout American history. We make these decisions available in a variety of formats through a variety of different access methods.

title: New Updates to Search: Advanced Filters
content: The Caselaw Access Project offers free, public access to over 6.5 million decisions published by state and federal courts throughout American history. Because our mission is providing access to legal information, we make these decisions available in a variety of formats through a variety of different access methods.

title: Exploring Caselaw Interfaces
content:
Courts and the legal publishers that serve them, by necessity, are
creatures of habit. A case's fundamental structure hasn't changed
much, whether published early in the 19th century or during the COVID
pandemic. Even when publishers started taking their wares online, they
didn't stray far from their well-worn model. In many ways, that's a good
thing. I imagine legal research and writing would be
creator: Drew (Andy) Silva

title: This Is Just Amazing
content: The other day, I noticed this on the side of the house.
creator: Ben Steinberg

title: Tech Tip: Sorting Cases on Analysis Fields
content:
Last month we
announced seven
new data fields in the
Caselaw Access Project. Here are API calls to the
cases endpoint that demonstrate how
to sort on these fields. Note the query strings, especially the use of
the minus sign (-) to reverse order.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Introducing CAP Case Analysis
content: We‚Äôre announcing a new layer of information in the Caselaw Access Project.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Summer 2020 CAP Systems Update
content: Today we‚Äôre sharing an update to Caselaw Access Project systems. This change shows one way libraries can support access to large datasets at low cost. Here‚Äôs how we did it.

title: Caselaw Access Project Cite Grid
content: Today we‚Äôre sharing Cite Grid, a first visualization of our citation graph data. Citation graphs are a way to see relationships between cases, and to answer questions like  ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the most cited jurisdiction?‚Äù and ‚ÄúWhat year was the most influential in U.S. case law?‚Äù
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Caselaw Access Project Data Release and Bulk Metadata
content: The latest update to CAP makes bulk downloads of case metadata available by jurisdiction and reporter. This release also includes the cites_to field in bulk downloads, refines case citations, and removes duplicate volumes.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Guest Post: An Empirical Study of Statutory Interpretation in Tax Law
content:
This guest post is part of the CAP Research Community Series. This series highlights research, applications, and projects created with Caselaw Access Project data.
Jonathan H. Choi is a Fellow at the New York University School of Law and will join the University of Minnesota Law School as an Associate Professor in August 2020. This post summarizes an article recently published in the May 2020 issu
creator: Jonathan H. Choi

title: Data Science for Case Law: A Course Collaboration
content: We just wrapped up a unique, semester-long collaboration between the Library and the data science program at SEAS.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Caselaw Access Project Nominated for a Webby: Vote for Us!
content: The Caselaw Access Project has been nominated for one of the 24th Annual Webby Awards. We‚Äôre honored to be named alongside this year‚Äôs other nominees, including friends and leaders in the field like the Knight First Amendment Institute.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Caselaw Access Project Citation Graph
content: The Caselaw Access Project is now sharing a citation graph of the 6.7 million cases in our collection from Harvard Law School Library. This update makes available a CSV file that lists case IDs and the cases they cite to. Here‚Äôs where you can find it: case.law/download/citation_graph
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Caselaw Access Project Shares PDFs for All Cases
content: The Caselaw Access Project is now making scanned PDFs available for every case in our collection.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Caselaw Access Project Links Case Citations
content: The Caselaw Access Project is taking its first steps to create links to case citations in our collection of 6.7 million cases.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: CAP Code Share: Caselaw Access Project API to CSV
content: Today we‚Äôre going to learn how to write case data from the Caselaw Access Project API to CSV. This post shows work from Jack Cushman, Senior Developer at the Harvard Library Innovation Lab.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Caselaw Access Project Downloads Now Available
content: Today we‚Äôre announcing CAP downloads, a new way to access select datasets relating to the Caselaw Access Project. While researchers can use our API and bulk data to access standardized metadata and text for all of the cases in the CAP dataset, we also want to make it possible to share specialized and derivative datasets.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Caselaw Access Project Shares Scanned Images for Open Jurisdictions
content: The Caselaw Access Project now has scanned images available for download as PDF, with selectable text, for all open-access jurisdictions, including Arkansas, Illinois, North Carolina and New Mexico. To download scanned images by volume, visit our downloads page and browse to the volume you seek: https://case.law/download/PDFs/open/.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Connecting Data with the Supreme Court Database (SCDB) and Caselaw Access Project
content: Last week we released an update to the Caselaw Access Project that adds case IDs and citations from the Supreme Court Database (SCDB) to our U.S. Supreme Court case metadata.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Some Recent Perma Use
content:
You may have seen Perma.cc links in a number of
documents of current interest, including the Trial Memorandum of the
U.S. House of Representatives in the Impeachment Trial of President
Donald
J. Trump
(archived at https://perma.cc/BG56-2KXH)
and the Trial Memorandum of President Donald
J. Trump
(archived at
https://perma.cc/XG5W-KRQF). Interestingly,
both documents cite Perma links without citing
creator: Ben Steinberg

title: North Carolina Joins Growing List of Open Access Jurisdictions
content: Today we‚Äôre pleased to announce that North Carolina has joined Illinois, Arkansas, and New Mexico as the latest jurisdiction to make all of its appellate court decisions openly available online, in an authoritative, machine-readable format that is citable using a vendor-neutral citation.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: The Open Casebook: Creating Casebooks with H2O and the Caselaw Access Project
content: What if you could create your own casebook with any case ever published? By connecting H2O open casebooks with the Caselaw Access Project, we can change how we read and create casebooks.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Guest Post: Is the US Supreme Court in lockstep with Congress when it comes to abortion?
content:
This guest post is part of the CAP Research Community Series. This series highlights research, applications, and projects created with Caselaw Access Project data.
Abdul Abdulrahim is a graduate student at the University of Oxford completing a DPhil in Computer Science. His primary interests are in the use of technology in government and law and developing neural-symbolic models that mitigate the
creator: Abdul Abdulrahim

title: Using Machine Learning to Extract Nuremberg Trials Transcript Document Citations
content: In Harvard‚Äôs Nuremberg Trials Project, being able to link to cited documents in each trial‚Äôs transcript is a key feature of site navigation. Each document submitted into evidence by prosecution and defense lawyers is introduced in the transcript and discussed, and the site user is offered the possibility at each document mention to click open the document and view its contents and attendant metada
creator: Rosa Lin, Scott Jones, and Paul Deschner

title: Getting Started with Caselaw Access Project Data
content: Today we‚Äôre sharing new ways to get started with Caselaw Access Project data using tutorials from The Programming Historian and more.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Guest Post: Creating a Case Recommendation System Using Gensim‚Äôs Doc2Vec
content:
This guest post is part of the CAP Research Community Series. This series highlights research, applications, and projects created with Caselaw Access Project data.
Minna Fingerhood graduated from the University of Pennsylvania this past May with a B.A. in Science, Technology, and Society (STSC) and Engineering Entrepreneurship. She is currently a data scientist in New York and is passionate about
creator: Minna Fingerhood

title: A Thought on Digitization
content:
Although it is excellent, and I recommend it very highly, 
I had not expected Roy Scranton‚Äôs Learning to Die in the
Anthropocene to shed light on the Caselaw Access
Project. Near the end of the book, he writes,
creator: Ben Steinberg

title: Creating a Data Analysis Workspace with Voyant and the CAP API
content: This tutorial is an introduction to creating a data analysis workspace with Voyant and the Caselaw Access Project API. Voyant is a computational analysis tool for text corpora.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Guest Post: Do Elected and Appointed Judges Write Opinions Differently?
content: Unlike anywhere else in the world, most judges in the United States today are elected. But it hasn‚Äôt always been this way. Over the past two centuries, the American states have taken a variety of different paths, alternating through a variety of elective and appointive methods.  Opponents of judicial elections charge that these institutions detract from judicial independence, harm the legitimacy o
creator: Michael Nelson and Steven Morgan

title: CAP Code Share: Get Opinion Author
content: This month we‚Äôre sharing new ways to start working with data from the Caselaw Access Project. This CAP code share from Anastasia Aizman shows us how to get opinion authors from cases with the CAP API and CourtListener: Get opinion author!
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Introducing Lawvocado: The Caselaw Access Project Newsletter
content: Today we‚Äôre sharing Lawvocado, our newsletter from the Caselaw Access Project.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Tutorial: Retrieve Cases by Citation with the CAP Case Browser
content: In this tutorial we‚Äôre going to learn how to retrieve a case by citation using the Caselaw Access Project‚Äôs case browser.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Computational Support for Statutory Interpretation with Caselaw Access Project Data
content: This post is about a research paper (preprint) on sentence retrieval for statutory interpretation that we presented at the International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Law (ICAIL 2019) held in June at Montreal, Canada. The paper describes some of our recent work on computational methods for statutory interpretation carried out at the University of Pittsburgh. The idea is to focus on vag
creator: Jaromir Savelka, Huihui Xu, Kevin D. Ashley

title: Tutorial: Return Cases from 100 Years Ago Today with the CAP API
content: The Caselaw Access Project API offers a way to view the corpus of U.S. case law. This tutorial will review how to run a CAP API call to return all cases decided 100 years ago today in your command line.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Caselaw Access Project: Summer 2019 Data Release
content:
Today we‚Äôre announcing a new data release for the Caselaw Access Project. This update includes:
In-text figures and illustrations in cases. An example, from Sussman v. Cooper (1976), is below.
Inline page numbers. You can provide a pin cite to a specific page in a case by adding #p123 to the URL, or just by clicking the page number.
Italic formatting in case text, as detected by OCR.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Caselaw Access Project Research Summit: Recordings Now Available
content: Last month we hosted the Caselaw Access Project Research Summit. An international group of researchers joined us to share what they are creating with Caselaw Access Project data. We are excited to share recordings of those presentations with you!
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Browse the Bookshelf of U.S. Case Law: Announcing the CAP Case Browser
content: Today we‚Äôre announcing the CAP case browser! Browse published U.S. case law from 1658 to 2018‚Äîall 40 million pages of it.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Teaching Data Science for Lawyers with Caselaw Access Project Data
content: In the Spring of 2019, at the University of Iowa, I taught an experimental course called Introduction to Quantitative & Computational Legal Reasoning. The idea of the class was beginning ‚Äúdata science‚Äù in the legal context. The course is taught in Python, and focuses on introductory coding and statistics, with focused applications in the law (such as statistical evidence of discrimination).
creator: Paul Gowder

title: The Caselaw Access Project Research Summit
content:
Since launching the CAP API and Bulk Data Service in Fall 2018, we‚Äôve been developing a research community around the Caselaw Access Project dataset.
Last week we hosted the first Caselaw Access Project Research Summit to bring together researchers from this community who had already made progress exploring data made available by the Caselaw Access Project.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Historical Trends at the Caselaw Access Project
content: Today we‚Äôre excited to share Historical Trends, a new way to explore U.S. case law made available by the Caselaw Access Project at Harvard Law School.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Improving pip-compile --generate-hashes
content:
Recently I landed a series of contributions to the Python package pip-tools:
Support URLs as packages #807
Fix ‚Äìgenerate-hashes with bare VCS URLs #812
Fix pip-compile output for unsafe requirements #813
Warn when ‚Äìgenerate-hashes output is uninstallable #814
creator: Jack Cushman

title: The CAP Roadshow
content: In 2019 we embarked on the CAP Roadshow. This year, we shared the Caselaw Access Project at conferences and workshops with new friends and colleagues.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Colors in Caselaw
content: The prospect of having the Caselaw Access Project dataset become public for the first time brings with it the obvious (and wholly necessary) ideas for data parsing: our dataset is vast and the metadata structured (read about the process to get to this), but the work of parsing the dataset is far from over. For instance, there‚Äôs a lot of work to be done in parsing individual parties in CAP (like na
creator: Anastasia Aizman

title: Launching CAP Search
content: Today we‚Äôre launching CAP search, a new interface to search data made available as part of the Caselaw Access Project API. Since releasing the CAP API in Fall 2018, this is our first try at creating a more human-friendly way to start working with this data.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Some Thoughts on Digital Preservation
content:
One of the things people often ask about Perma.cc
is how we ensure the preservation of Perma links.
creator: Ben Steinberg

title: Developing the CAP Research Community
content: Since launching the Caselaw Access Project API and bulk data service in October, we‚Äôve been lucky to see a research community develop around this dataset. Today, we‚Äôre excited to share examples of how that community is using CAP data to create new kinds of legal scholarship.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: The Network Librarian
content:
Last year,
Jack Cushman
expressed a desire for a personal service similar to the one I perform
here at LIL ‚Äì not exactly the
DevOps of my job title, but
more generally the provision and maintenance of network and computing
infrastructure. Jack‚Äôs take on this idea is very much a personal one,
I think: go to a person known to and trusted by you, not the
proverbial faceless corporation, for whom you
creator: Ben Steinberg

title: Data Stories and CAP API Full-Text Search
content: Data sets have tales to tell. In the Caselaw Access Project API, full-text search is a way to find these stories in 300+ years of U.S caselaw, from individual cases to larger themes.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Legal Tech Student Group Session Brings Quantitative Methods to U.S. Caselaw
content: This September we hosted a Legal Tech Gumbo session dedicated to using quantitative methods to find new threads in U.S. caselaw. The Legal Tech Gumbo is a collaboration between the Harvard Law & Technology Society and Harvard Library Innovation Lab (LIL).
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: The Story of the case.law Domain
content: Recently we announced the launch of the Caselaw Access Project at case.law. But we want to highlight the story of the case.law domain itself.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Witchcraft in U.S. Caselaw
content:
Happy Halloween!
This Halloween is a special one at LIL, since we‚Äôre celebrating the release of the Caselaw Access Project and 360 years of digitized U.S. caselaw.
For a small project using our full text search functionality, we mapped out the usage of the term ‚Äúwitchcraft‚Äù in United States caselaw.
creator: Anastasia Aizman

title: Caselaw Access Project (CAP) Launches API and Bulk Data Service
content: Today the Library Innovation Lab at the Harvard Law School Library is excited to announce the launch of its Caselaw Access Project (CAP) API and bulk data service, which puts the full corpus of published U.S. case law online for anyone to access for free.
creator: Kelly Fitzpatrick

title: Telling Stories with CAP Data: The Prolific Mr. Cartwright
content: When I think about data, caselaw isn‚Äôt the first thing that comes to mind.
creator: John Bowers
